data: Funerary inscription for Lucius Cassius Hermes

A rectangular marble plaque, intact on all sides (minor
                                            chipping to the lower edge), finished on the reverse.

Latin text over seven lines. Line 1 is centred, lines 2-7
                                        maintain the left margin. There is some compression of the letters lower right.

Letters show a cursive tendency. The foot of P, T, I extends notably
                                    to the right; F and R have trailing lower strokes. Simple interpuncts between words.
End 1st century CE or 2nd century CE (so Korhonen)
Found, together with  (inv.393), in 1736 in a Roman tomb in the area of Porta Aci / Porta di Jaci, now Piazza Stesicoro.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana
Castello Ursino, Piazza Federico II di Svevia, 95121 Catania (CT)
Inscriptiones Bruttiorum Lucaniae Campaniae Siciliae Sardiniae Latinae. Pars posterior. Inscriptiones Siciliae et Sardiniae

T. Mommsen, Inscriptiones Bruttiorum Lucaniae Campaniae Siciliae Sardiniae Latinae. Pars posterior. Inscriptiones Siciliae et Sardiniae, Corpus Inscriptionum Latinarum, consilio et auctoritate Academiae Litterarum Regiae Borussicae editum, 10.2 (Berlin: G. Reimer, 1883)
Le iscrizioni del Museo civico di Catania : storia delle collezioni, cultura epigrafica, edizione
Kalle Korhonen, Le iscrizioni del Museo civico di Catania : storia delle collezioni, cultura epigrafica, edizione (Helsinki: Societas Scientiarum Fennica, 2004)

Dis manibus sacrum Lucius Cassius Hermes optimus virorum vixit annis LX IIII filii posuerunt patri merenti

1D·M·S·
2L·CASSIUS
3HERMES·
4OPTIMUS·
5VIRORUM·
6VIX·ANN·LX
7IIII·F·P·P·M·

DISMANIBUSSACRUMLUCIUSCASSIUSHERMESOPTIMUSVIRORUMVIXITANNISLXIIIIFILIIPOSUERUNTPATRIMERENTI

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

English translation

Jonathan Prag

Sacred to the spirits of the underworld. Lucius Cassius Hermes, best of men, lived for 60 years. His four children set this up for a deserving father.

Italian translation

Serena Agodi

Consacrato agli Dei Mani, Lucio Cassio Hermes, ottimo tra gli uomini, visse 60 anni. I quattro figli posero per il padre meritevole.

commentary

The deceased is a Roman citizen. The Greek cognomen, ‘Hermes’ suggests that he or one of his ancestors was either a Greek Sicilian or a freed slave. The phrase optimus virorum is unusual and so is the last line: abbreviations are very common in Latin epigraphy, but they are not always easy to resolve - epigraphers solve them by comparing with other texts, but this does not have an exact parallel.

This inscription was found in or near the same tomb as ISic000378. The style of the inscriptions is similar, but the form of the letters is not identical, and the texts were engraved by different people. They could be approximately contemporary. It is impossible to know if Tyche and Hermes were related.

The deceased is a Roman citizen. The Greek cognomen, ‘Hermes’ suggests that he or one of his ancestors was either a Greek Sicilian or a freed slave.
